conclusion: From t = 0 to the dashed centre-line the speed first decreases to zero, then becomes negative and reaches a largest negative value.
After the centre-line everything happens symmetrically in reverse order until t = t₁.
Because the left-hand and right-hand parts of the graph are mirror images, any area swept out in the first half is swept out once more in the second half.

If a chosen reference position corresponds to a certain shaded area A, the graph can produce that same area three times: once while the velocity is still positive, once while the velocity is negative, and once again after the centre-line when the motion repeats in reverse order.

Translate the areas into positions reached on the x-axis: a typical sequence that leads to the same coordinate x being taken three times is (i) 0 < t < tₐ : the particle is moving forward but slowing. It reaches x at t = tₐ.
(ii) tₐ < t < t_b : the particle has reversed direction, moves backward past the same point, meeting x again at t = t_b.
(iii) t_b < t < t_c ( = t₁ − tₐ ) : now it has reversed once more (velocity positive) and crosses x for the third time at t = t_c.
Case 1 – “slow-fast-slow”: First crossing: decelerating forward motion. Second crossing: accelerating backward motion. Third crossing: decelerating backward-to-forward motion (mirror of the first).

Case 2 – “fast-slow-fast”: First crossing: accelerating forward motion (if the reference x is taken nearer the origin). Second crossing: decelerating backward motion. Third crossing: accelerating forward motion.
Case 3 – “symmetrical about the centre-line”: crossing exactly midway gives two adjoining but opposite-direction crossings, then a mirror repeat.
The key requirement for “three-times” is that the chosen position lies between the forward turning point (left of the dashed line) and the backward turning point (centre minimum).
Any such position is reached once during the initial forward run, once while the particle is going backward, and once again during the final forward run.
Within 0 ≤ t ≤ t₁ the particle can pass through the same point in space three times provided that point lies between the particle’s first turning point and its second turning point.
A representative description of the motion is: 1) forward motion while slowing down, 2) backward motion while speeding up, 3) forward motion while speeding up again (mirror image of stage 1).
Because the v–t graph is symmetric, every such interior point is crossed exactly three times; points outside that range are crossed once or not at all.
